title: How do YouTubers upload copyrighted videos and monetize them without getting a copyright strike? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can not monetize a video that is flagged as copyrighted by someone else. However, in some cases, you certainly can upload copyrighted videos and YouTube will send an email, but they do not penalize you. I have heard sometimes they send an email that does penalize you, but I’ve uploaded dozens of copyrighted songs with no penalty. I don’t know what the difference is, why I am able to do it, but others can’t. Once again, even if YouTube allows you to upload the video, which they may, they will not let you monetize it, because they will monetize it themself. So, when you see the ad running on the video, the money is not going to the channel. The reasoning is based on YouTube’s interest in having a full music catalog, which is not perfectly in sync with the site’s original design, and name (You- TUBE, which is a VIDEO site). At some point, they simply realized they had a more complete music catalog than Spotify, and more diverse. So now they have “YouTube Music.” They already had all the songs, uploaded by users. Same way Google built 3-D cities in their “Earth” program - by allowing users to submit the content, and paying no-one for doing all the uploads. Consider all the material from artists who recorded pre-YouTube, like old James Taylor songs. They’re all in there, most of them with no valid video content whatsoever, and none of them uploaded by YouTube or James Taylor. All user contributed content. If you’re wondering why I can do it, I’m not sure, but I’ll give you a few details about what I do, and it may be different than what you’ve tried. First, I have 18-thousand subscribers and have been running a channel for years; that might make a difference. However, the bulk of my growth was due to a multi-million view video I posted of a French singer (Alizee), content which I thought was terrific (and others agreed!), but which I don’t own the rights to. When I posted that video, YouTube was changing. In previous years I did get videos taken down every now and then. But in the past few years, YouTube’s monitoring (Shazam-style) of uploaded “music” (even in the background) has gotten more sophisticated, and their agreements with license holders have become vastly widespread. Those things seem to be related to the change. In the past five years or more, I have never had a violation. I do get an email that informs me I can’t monetize the video, but YouTube cut me off from monetization years-ago in a strange way (a different story altogether)! These days, I often create high-quality videos of bands. The emails I receive are not copyright strikes (screenshot of email below):  So, to answer your question, two things: First, you can’t monetize - no channel owner can; Santana will monetize it through his agency. Second, how do some people do it? I don’t know, but I do it all the time! Here’s a shameless link to my YouTube channel: Music Video Network. Hope that helps; happy uploading!
